newsitem.title: GERMANY: Dry weather could boost EU malting barley prices.
newsitem.headline: Dry weather could boost EU malting barley prices.

text.p: European malting barley prices could rise unless a number of key producer countries receive more rain, specialist broker Jochen Mautner GmbH said.
The broker surveyed plantings progress in spring barley, of which a large percentage qualifies for malting purposes.
He said European spring barley sowings, which had started in February, were nearly complete, with Finland and some regions in Sweden still outstanding.
Outside the EU, Poland and the Czech republic had not yet planted the bulk of the crop.
The weather had been almost perfect in the early stages but turned dry in April so that Spain, France, Britain and Denmark were complaining about deteriorating prospects.
Malting barley prices had been weighed down by initially good crop prospects and unsold tonnages from an excellent harvest last year but this could change if the weather turned against crops.
The 1997 EU spring barley area may be stable or up to two percent above last year's, Mautner said.
Last November, he estimated the 1996 spring barley area at 6.05 million hectares.
Mautner listed intended spring barley areas as follows (in ha) but gave no forecast of the potential malting barley crop.
